Introduction

Placenta accreta spectrum describes the abnormal placental attachment to the myometrium, which creates a morbidly adherent placenta.  PAS is categorized by depth of abnormal placental invasion (

figure 1
):

  • Placenta accreta: placental attachment to the myometrium
  • Placenta increta: placental attachment/invasion into partially into the myometrium
  • Placenta percreta (most severe): complete placental penetration through the myometrium to the uterine serosa, and potentially into adjacent structures (eg, bladder)

Pathogenesis

The uterus has 3 layers: the serosa (outermost layer adjacent to other pelvic structures [eg, bladder]), the myometrium (middle layer of smooth muscle), and the endometrium (inner layer lining the uterine cavity).

In early pregnancy, progesterone stimulates endometrial decidualization, transforming the endometrium into the decidua basalis.  Normally, trophoblasts (which develop into the placenta) attach to this specialized endometrial layer because it promotes placental growth.  As it thickens, the decidua becomes a distinct tissue plane separating the developing placenta and myometrium.  After delivery, declining progesterone stimulates breakdown of the decidua; along with uterine contractions, this applies a shearing force to the weakened decidual layer.  As a result, the placenta and decidua basalis spontaneously detach, and the placenta is delivered minutes after the fetus.

In placenta accreta, there are areas of absent or defective endometrial decidualization due to preexisting endometrial damage, most commonly scarring from uterine surgery (eg, cesarean delivery, dilation and curettage, myomectomy).  In these cases, trophoblasts migrate through defects in the decidua and attach to the deeper myometrium.  The trophoblasts then form chorionic villi containing lacunae (spaces filled with maternal blood); as the chorionic villi branch and expand, the placenta slowly invades the myometrium.

At delivery, the placenta is morbidly adherent because areas with direct placental-myometrial attachment do not have decidua basalis breakdown nor an anatomic plane between the placenta and uterus.  Therefore, attempted placental removal yields only placental fragments and precipitates profuse bleeding and maternal hemorrhage.

Risk factors

Due to a shared pathogenesis (ie, endometrial damage due to prior uterine surgery), placenta accreta is commonly associated with placenta previa (

figure 2
), or abnormally low placentation causing placental tissue to cover the cervix.  Therefore, the greatest risk for placenta accreta occurs in women with â‰¥1 prior cesarean delivery PLUS placenta previa in the current pregnancy.  The combination of these 2 factors poses a greater risk than either risk factor alone because both have the potential to cause massive hemorrhage.

However, >50% of cases of placenta accreta occur in patients without placenta previa and prior cesarean delivery, possibly due to smaller endometrial defects or generalized endometrial dysfunction.  Additional risk factors may include prior dilation and curettage, pelvic irradiation, and postpartum endometritis as well as multiparity, advanced maternal age, and in vitro fertilization.  Uterine pathology (eg, bicornuate uterus, submucosal fibroids) can cause microscopic endometrial defects, which may explain why rare cases occur in primigravidas with no prior uterine surgery.

Clinical presentation

Placenta accreta can present in 3 ways:

  • Most commonly, placenta acccreta presents as an incidental finding on routine second-trimester prenatal ultrasound.  A concomitant placenta previa or a low-lying placenta may be present.
  • Placenta accreta can present with antepartum bleeding, with or without fetal distress.  Bleeding related to a concomitant placenta previa is usually painless; placental invasion into adjacent structures can cause painful bleeding and hematuria (eg, placenta percreta).
  • Occasionally, placenta accreta is not diagnosed until delivery (eg, due to limited/absent prenatal care); it should be suspected in patients with postpartum hemorrhage who present with:
    • A morbidly adherent placenta in which a plane cannot be developed between the placenta and uterine wall for placental removal (after vaginal delivery), or
    • Bulging, blue-purple lower uterine segment, increased uterine serosa vascularity, and visible placental invasion (after repeat cesarean delivery)

Even in asymptomatic patients with an antepartum diagnosis, placenta accreta can cause severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).  Hysterectomy for hemorrhage control and multiple blood transfusions may be required.  Hemorrhagic shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and maternal death can occur without timely management.

Diagnosis

The primary tool for diagnosing PAS is ultrasound, regardless of the clinical presentation.  Ultrasound provides real-time assessment of placental location, vascularity, and depth of invasion.  The most common ultrasound findings include:

  • Concomitant placenta previa
  • Signs of an invasive placenta:  myometrial thinning, numerous placental lacunae, myometrial invasion (eg, placenta increta), and disrupted uterine-bladder interface (eg, placenta percreta)

Magnetic resonance imaging may be performed for detailed assessment and surgical planning.  The diagnosis is confirmed intraoperatively and on histopathology, which reveals placental villi anchored onto, into, or through the myometrium without an intervening decidual plate.

Differential diagnosis

Placenta accreta can present with antepartum bleeding or severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Antepartum bleeding, the following are considered:

  • Placenta previa (
    figure 3
    ):  most common placental disorder associated with placenta accreta.  Can cause painless bleeding any time before delivery but particularly with contractions or rupture of membranes.  Fetal heart rate tracing is initially reassuring because blood loss is maternal.  Significant maternal hemorrhage leads to fetal heart rate abnormalities.
  • Placental abruption (
    figure 4
    ):  can cause painful antepartum bleeding; contractions every 1-2 minutes; a firm, tender uterus; and fetal heart rate abnormalities.  However, due to premature placental detachment prior to fetal delivery, placental delivery is usually rapid.
  • Uterine rupture (
    figure 5
    ):  also associated with prior cesarean delivery.  Can present with bleeding, severe abdominal pain, and fetal distress, usually during labor.  Placental delivery is typically spontaneous and extrauterine structures are usually not involved.
  • Vasa previa (
    figure 6
    ):  can cause painless antepartum bleeding and rapid fetal decline because blood loss is fetal (not maternal) in origin.

Postpartum hemorrhage, the differential includes:

  • Retained placenta and/or products of conception:  causes PPH but the anatomic plane between the placenta and uterus is intact; therefore, manual placental removal is possible and improves bleeding.
  • Intraamniotic infection:  can cause both difficult placental delivery (ie, inflamed, adherent placenta) and PPH (ie, poor uterine contractility).  Manual removal is possible and improves bleeding.
  • Uterine atony (ie, poor uterine contractility):  the most common cause of PPH.  Presents with a soft, boggy uterus, and bleeding continues after placental removal.

Management

Bleeding associated with placenta accreta can occur at any time before delivery, but the highest maternal morbidity occurs after delivery due to postpartum hemorrhage.  Management for severe maternal hemorrhage usually includes multiple blood transfusions plus hysterectomy to prevent coagulopathy and maternal death.

Therefore, antepartum diagnosis is critical.  In asymptomatic patients diagnosed antepartum, management typically includes:

  • Planned cesarean hysterectomy (ie, cesarean delivery immediately followed by hysterectomy) at 34-36 weeks gestation (ie, prior to spontaneous labor)
  • Routine antepartum care:  pelvic rest (eg, avoidance of sexual activity) and follow-up ultrasound at 32-34 weeks gestation to assess bladder involvement.
  • Antenatal corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity
  • Potential third-trimester hospitalization because timely intervention (ie, emergency cesarean delivery within 20 minutes of bleeding) decreases morbidity and mortality

Delivery planning requires consideration of timing, location, availability of blood products, and the coordination of multidisciplinary teams.  Although cesarean hysterectomy is planned for 34-36 weeks gestation, sooner delivery may be appropriate in the setting of clinically significant bleeding, preterm labor, rupture of membranes, and other standard obstetric indications (eg, fetal distress).

If placenta accreta is suspected during or after delivery (ie, delayed presentation), patients require immediate transport to an operating room for evaluation (eg, ultrasound).  The placenta should be left in situ and not disturbed once placenta accreta is suspected.

Prevention

Delayed diagnosis of PAS significantly increases both maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.  Therefore, all patients are recommended routine second-trimester prenatal ultrasound at 18-24 weeks gestation.  Patients with placenta previa, low anterior placenta, or prior uterine surgery require both transabdominal and transvaginal evaluation of the placenta-myometrium interface.

Prognosis

The prognosis of PAS depends on various factors, including the depth of placental invasion and involved structures, extent of intraoperative or postpartum bleeding, timeliness of management, and availability of resources.  The combined presence of PAS and placenta previa is associated with increased fetal and maternal morbidity compared to PAS alone.

Summary

Placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) (
